summaries.body: China added one million millionaires (in U.S. dollars) last year as a result of stock market gains, according to a new report by the Boston Consulting Group.
A North Korean soldier defected to South Korea on Monday, walking across the southern half of the Demilitarized Zone that separates the rival countries.
Nearly two months after the devastating earthquake in Nepal, the country's heritage sites are set to reopen to the public, despite safety concerns raised by Unesco.

posts.footer: The most recent fatality brings the death toll to 16, according to the South Korean Health Ministry, via Twitter

summaries.body: MERS cases in South Korea rise to 150 with five more, one death http://t.co/kIw8P77IyU

posts.footer: Luis Garcia, a University of Southern California student who participated in a poll on sexual consent, via The Washington Post

summaries.body: It’s more like a physical affirmation. That’s hard to judge when either party might be intoxicated or impaired. It does become super hard to explicitly define what should be said and what should be done.
A teenage girl lost part of her arm and a teenage boy was severely injured in separate shark attacks in the waters off Oak Island, N.C., on Sunday.

display_asset.caption: One of dozens of animals to have escaped amid flooding in the main zoo in Tbilisi, Georgia, a hippopotamus was coaxed away from dangerous waters on Sunday.

summaries.body: Dozens of animals are on the loose in the capital city of Georgia, after heavy rains destroyed the enclosures of Tbilisi’s main zoo. At least 12 people died in the floods.
Dave Grohl, the Foo Fighters frontman, fell off a stage in Sweden and said he thought he broke his leg, but he returned to continue the concert. Above, before the fall.
The U.S. State Department said that there were technical problems with its overseas passport and visa systems but that they would be "fully operational again soon."
The singer and songwriter Van Morrison was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II for his services to music and tourism in Northern Ireland, where he was born.
At least 400 million people lack access to essential health services, the World Health Organization and World Bank said in a report they described as a wake-up call.
Flights to the Galápagos Islands were canceled Friday as residents protested legislation that would get rid of wage subsidies for public and private workers.
A judge granted the Arizona Coyotes' request for a temporary injunction to stop Glendale from voiding the team's $225 million agreement to play at Gila River Arena.
Secretary of State John Kerry, who was released from a hospital on Friday, said he would be "totally engaged" in the Iran nuclear talks despite his broken leg.
A Texas regulator said there was no evidence that injecting oilfield waste into wells caused the largest recorded earthquake in the history of North Texas last month.
Google announced that this summer it would release YouTube Gaming, a mobile application and website that will focus on video games, videos and live streams.
Barry Manilow will headline the Independence Day celebration on the National Mall in Washington on July 4, which will be broadcast on PBS and NPR at 8 p.m.

display_asset.caption: Jason Whitlock, one of the country’s most prominent African-American sportswriters, will stay at ESPN, mostly in a writing role.

summaries.body: Jason Whitlock is out as head of the Undefeated, the website ESPN was building around his personality to examine sports through the prism of race.
Tonya Carpenter, who was seriously injured by a shattered baseball bat at a Red Sox game last week, has been released from the hospital and is in good condition.
The Waco, Tex., police chief said on Friday that officers fired 12 rounds during the deadly shootout among rival biker gangs in May and "did not fire indiscriminately."
A State Department spokesman said North Korea's accusations that the U.S. is targeting the country with anthrax are ridiculous and don't merit a response.
The former New England Patriots linebacker Brandon Spikes was charged with speeding and driving negligently before a crash on Sunday. The Patriots released him on Monday.
Pope Francis said he would visit the Central African Republic and Uganda this fall, and hoped to visit Kenya but "it is still uncertain." It'll be his first trip to Africa as pope.
U.N. peace talks with Yemen's two main warring parties in Geneva have been postponed until Monday. Above, an airstrike hit an area declared a Unesco World Heritage Site.
An appeals court in Louisiana decided to continue to block the release of Albert Woodfox, who has spent more than 40 years in solitary confinement.
Standard & Poor's downgraded its outlook for Britain to negative because of risks posed by the country's potential departure from the European Union.
"Jurassic World" earned $18.5 million at the box office Thursday night, Universal's biggest late-night showing ever.
Three climbers have been reported stranded at 14,000 feet on Mount Rainier in Washington State, and officials confirmed a rescue is taking place.
Secretary of State John Kerry will be released from a hospital in Boston on Friday afternoon. He had surgery after breaking his leg in a bicycle accident in France.

display_asset.caption: A chimpanzee in the Abidjan zoo in the Ivory Coast. All chimpanzees will be labeled as endangered by the United States Fish and Wildlife service starting later this year.

summaries.body: All chimpanzees will be designated as endangered under the U.S. Endangered Species Act, in a decision that removes a distinction between captive and wild chimpanzees.
Interpol said it would stop using financial contributions from FIFA to fight corruption in soccer, citing the U.S. investigations that have ensnared soccer’s governing body.
Sierra Leone's president has imposed new restrictions on entering or leaving two areas in the northern part of the country that are experiencing a resurgence of Ebola.
Scientists have observed polar bears eating dolphins in the Norwegian Arctic, where warming waters are changing the ecosystem and relations between species, a study said.
Jeni's Splendid Ice Creams found listeria in its production facility for the second time and has stopped production, but said all of the ice cream sold in its shops has been safe.

display_asset.credit: Richard Brooks/The Pew Charitable Trusts, via A.P.

summaries.body: The Pacific nation of Palau, fighting a rising tide of illegal fishing in its waters, set fire to four Vietnamese boats poaching sea cucumbers and other marine life in its waters.
An armed group attacked Tunisia's consulate in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, and kidnapped 10 staff members, the Tunisian Foreign Ministry said on Friday.
Two men were charged in Boston with trying to provide material support to ISIS, in a case related to the investigation of a suspect shot dead by officers this month.
A Japan Airlines pilot has been suspended after he let a flight attendant sit in the co-pilot's chair during a flight and then took a picture with her on his smartphone.
France’s privacy regulator called on Google to apply a European decree, the so-called right to be forgotten ruling, to its global domains or face financial penalties.
Princess Cristina of Spain was stripped of the title Duchess of Palma by her brother, King Felipe VI. She is to stand trial soon on charges of tax fraud and money laundering.
The parents of a prominent civil rights leader in Washington State said their daughter had been falsely portraying herself as black for years. City officials are investigating.
Four tourists were sentenced to three days in jail in Malaysia on charges of committing obscene acts in public. They will be released for time served after paying a fine.
The South Yorkshire Police will not be investigated over their handling of clashes between miners and officers at a coking plant in 1984, the British police watchdog said.
Bank account holders in Zimbabwe will soon be able to convert their balance into U.S. dollars. The new exchange rate: $1 for 35,000,000,000,000,000 old dollars.
Walter De Gregorio, the chief spokesman for world soccer’s governing body, has stepped down amid speculation that he was forced out for a joke about the FIFA president.
The World Food Program is reducing Kenyan refugees' rations by 30 percent, in what it said was an emergency move to conserve dwindling supplies and funds.
South Korea reported an 11th death from its outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome. Above, workers disinfected a hall to try to prevent the spread of the virus.

display_asset.caption: Belmont Stakes ticketholders have until March 31 to collect their winnings; as of Monday afternoon, over 90,000 tickets remained unclaimed.

summaries.body: More than 90,000 winning tickets from American Pharoah’s Triple Crown victory are still unclaimed. Some bettors decided their tickets would fetch more on eBay.

posts.footer: The Sydney Morning Herald | The Guardian

summaries.body: Prime Minister Tony Abbott refused to say whether Australia had paid human traffickers to turn back at sea, but he said officials had found "creative" ways to fight the "evil trade."
An avant-garde Slovenian rock band dating from the 1980s, Laibach, said it would perform in North Korea in August during commemorations of Japan's defeat in World War II.

posts.footer: Jagendra Singh, an Indian journalist, writing on Facebook days before he was fatally attacked by men he said were allies of an official he had accused of corruption, via The New York Times

summaries.body: At this time, politicians, thugs, and police, all are after me. Writing the truth is weighing heavily on my life.

posts.footer: The Guardian | The New York Times

summaries.body: Britain is reviewing its advice for citizens headed to Malaysia after a British woman and three others were detained, accused of taking nude photos on a mountain.
A state-run magazine in China chided Communist Party cadres for not reading enough, noting that "not a single book could be found" in one disgraced official's mansion.
Saturn's biggest ring is even bigger than scientists previously thought, spanning an area nearly 7,000 times as large as the planet itself, according to new research.
The singer Jim Ed Brown, a 2015 inductee into the Country Music Hall of Fame, died Thursday in Tennessee at age 81. He was being treated for cancer.
The Pakistani authorities shut down the aid group Save the Children’s office in Islamabad and ordered its foreign staff members to leave the country within 15 days.
Ahead of a U.N. commission report, the Israeli military said no laws were broken in several attacks that led to civilian deaths during last summer's war in the Gaza Strip.
Two national television reporters may face court sanctions for trying to question J. Dennis Hastert, a former speaker of the House, at his arraignment on criminal charges.
King Felipe VI of Spain has stripped his sister, Princess Cristina, of her title as Duchess of Palma. She and her husband face tax evasion charges.
Kurds lined a road in Turkey as the body of Keith Broomfield, an American who died fighting with Kurdish forces against the Islamic State, was returned to his family.
Jack King, a NASA official who counted down the historic launch of Apollo 11 in 1969, died Thursday at a hospice facility not far from Kennedy Space Center. He was 84.
Reeling from a cyberattack that stole information from thousands of taxpayers, the I.R.S. announced a sweeping effort to step up protections against identity theft.
Charges were dropped against Martese Johnson, a University of Virginia student who was arrested outside a bar in March. A photo of his bloody face sparked an outcry.
A former inmate at Guantánamo Bay, Mourad Benchellali, was stopped from boarding a flight from France to Canada because it would fly through U.S. airspace.
A federal court denied requests that would stop the new net neutrality rules from taking effect on Friday, but did grant an expedited hearing of the case.
Hulu is re-creating Jerry's apartment in "Seinfeld" as the show debuts on the streaming service. It'll be open to the public from June 24-28 in Manhattan's West Village.
The chairman of the Boston Public Library has resigned following the furor surrounding the disappearance — and rediscovery — of prints by Albrecht Durer and Rembrandt.

display_asset.caption: Michelle Obama — who has been on More magazine’s cover twice previously — helped choose the columns and articles for the July/August issue, many of which are connected to her wide-reaching initiatives.

summaries.body: Michelle Obama will be the guest editor of the July-August issue of the women's lifestyle magazine More, a first for any first lady. The issue will be out June 23.
Whole Foods Market revealed the name of a new line of stores focused on millennials: 365 by Whole Foods Market. The chain will open in 2016.
Kenya set a goal to get 100,000 Somali refugees to return home voluntarily by the end of the year, as money shortages have forced the U.N. to reduce food rations.
The Center for Reproductive Rights and the A.C.L.U. filed a lawsuit to halt a Florida law, signed Wednesday, that requires women seeking an abortion to wait 24 hours.

display_asset.credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times

summaries.body: The New York Knicks star Carmelo Anthony will be a part-owner of Puerto Rico F.C., an expansion team in the North American Soccer League, the league announced.
Raees Alam Qazi, right, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for plotting to blow up New York City landmarks. His brother, Sheheryar Qazi, was given 20 years in prison.
A union official said that hackers stole the Social Security number of every federal employee in a recently disclosed cyberattack.
The body of Tariq Aziz, Saddam Hussein's former top aide who died last week in prison, has gone missing from a Baghdad airport, his daughter said.
The United States has spent more than $2.74 billion — about $9.1 million a day — fighting the Islamic State, according to the Pentagon's first cost breakdown.
Paraguay's Congress voted to withdraw immunity from the Conmebol soccer federation's Asunción headquarters, which had been exempt from being searched since 1997.
A fired executive sued Al Jazeera America, criticizing the integrity of its news coverage and treatment of its employees.
Three weeks after lifting a unilateral cease-fire with the Colombian government, FARC, the largest rebel group, has stepped up attacks on the energy infrastructure.
A group of 17 political parties agreed to boycott elections in Burundi because they don't believe they will be free and fair, an opposition leader said.
The long-awaited consumer version of Oculus Rift, the virtual reality headset, debuted in San Francisco and is scheduled to go on sale to the public in 2016.
Virgil Runnels, known as the American Dream Dusty Rhodes as a professional wrestler, died on Thursday. He was 69.
An amendment to a defense spending bill that would have forced Congress to vote on authorizing military force against the Islamic State was defeated in the House.
The commission that accredits the University of North Carolina gave the school 12 months of probation, its most serious sanction, for an academic and athletics scandal.

posts.footer: The New York Times via Facebook

summaries.body: David Guttenfelder, a photojournalist and National Geographic Fellow, answered reader questions on Facebook about his visit to North Korea.
A court in Egypt convicted and sentenced a police officer to 15 years in prison over the killing of a female protester, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, during a peaceful demonstration.
Gordon Fox, the former Rhode Island House speaker, was sentenced to three years in prison for corruption. In court, he described himself as a lawbreaker and a disgrace.
Eritrea denied that it subjects its citizens to indefinite national service or kills people trying to flee the country, two of a U.N. investigation's most serious findings.
The comedian Colin Quinn will return to the New York stage in a new show that takes a satirical look at his hometown and its history. Jerry Seinfeld will direct.
FIFA's head of communications, Walter De Gregorio, resigned on Thursday. He made headlines on Monday for a joke about the soccer governing body on Swiss TV.
Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton, saying she has failed to share her views on issues including trade and climate change.
Spain’s Parliament approved a long-awaited law devised to open the way for citizenship for thousands of Sephardic Jews whose ancestors were expelled in 1492.
The state House in North Carolina overrode the governor's veto of a bill that allows magistrates to decline to perform same-sex marriages, making the bill law.
A Virginia teenager admitted in court that he was behind a pro-Islamic State Twitter account and helped another teen travel to join the group in Syria.
Gov. Peter Shumlin said there would be increased police presence across Vermont after two convicts escaped from a New York prison, but "they could be anywhere."
The International Monetary Fund said “major differences remain” in debt negotiations with Greece, adding that “we are well away from an agreement.”
For the first time, the Federal Trade Commission took action against a crowdfunded project, agreeing to settle with board game makers who never made the funded game.
Three astronauts from the International Space Station returned to Earth after about 200 days in space. They landed in Kazakhstan.
The British government is reviewing its advice for travel to Malaysia after a woman was arrested there for posing naked on a mountain. Her family apologized on her behalf.
Fighters from the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda’s branch in Syria, killed at least 20 members of the Druse sect, fueling fears over how it treats civilians and minorities as it advances.
